content.heading: Introduction to One Person Company (OPC)
description: One Person Company (OPC) registration in India was introduced as a concept under the Companies Act of 2013, enabling a single individual to establish a company and enjoy the combined benefits of both a sole proprietorship and a traditional company structure. This concept became available with the implementation of the Companies Act in 2013.

The primary objective behind creating one-person companies was to foster entrepreneurship and encourage the formalization of Micro, Small, and Medium Enterprises (MSMEs). According to Section 2(62) of the Companies Act 2013, a company can be formed with just one director and one member, and interestingly, these roles can be held by the same individual. Simply, OPC Company registration allows a single person to set up a limited liability company in India. The following describes the eligibility and procedure to register one person company.

content.heading: Eligibility Criteria
content.overview: Before you go ahead and engage in OPC registration process, it's crucial to understand the specific eligibility criteria and limitations that govern its formation. The Companies Act sets out clear requirements that must be met to ensure that the individual promoting the OPC is eligible to do so.

criteria.title: Natural Person and Indian Citizen
criteria.description: Only a natural person who is an Indian citizen can establish an OPC. Legal entities like companies or LLPs cannot create an OPC.

criteria.title: Resident in India
criteria.description: The promoter must be a resident in India, meaning they should have lived in India for at least 182 days during the previous calendar year.

criteria.title: Minimum Authorized Capital
criteria.description: The OPC must have a minimum authorized capital of Rs 1 00,000, the amount stated in the company's capital clause during the OPC Company registration.

criteria.title: Nominee Appointment
criteria.description: The promoter must appoint a nominee during the OPC's incorporation. This nominee would become a member of the OPC in the event of the promoter's death or incapacity.

criteria.title: Restrictions on Certain Businesses
criteria.description: Businesses involved in financial activities such as banking, insurance, or investments are not eligible for OPC company registration.

criteria.title: Conversion to Private Limited Company
criteria.description: If the OPC's paid-up share capital exceeds 50 lakhs or its average annual turnover surpasses 2 Crores, it must be converted into a private limited company to comply with the regulatory requirements for larger companies.

items.title: Legal Status
items.description: An OPC obtains a separate legal entity status, safeguarding the individual who founded it from personal liability for company losses.

items.title: Easy Fundraising
items.description: Being a private company, OPCs find it easier to raise funds through venture capitalists, angel investors, and banks compared to proprietorship firms.

items.title: Reduced Compliance
items.description: OPCs enjoy certain exemptions from compliance requirements under the Companies Act, 2013, simplifying administrative obligations.

items.title: Simple Incorporation
items.description: OPCs can be established with just one member and one nominee, with the member also serving as the director. No minimum paid-up capital requirement simplifies the incorporation process.

items.title: Efficient Management
items.description: With a single person managing the OPC, decision-making is swift, leading to efficient company management without conflicts or delays.

items.title: Perpetual Succession
items.description: OPCs maintain perpetual succession, ensuring the company's continuity even with only one member.

items.title: Suitable for Small Businesses
items.description: OPCs are primarily suitable for small-scale businesses as they can only have one member. This limits their ability to raise additional capital as the business expands.

items.title: Restriction on Business Activities
items.description: OPCs are restricted from engaging in certain activities, such as non-banking financial investments and charitable objectives. Hence, companies with these business activities are not eligible for OPC company registration.

items.title: Ownership and Management
items.description: There's a lack of clear distinction between ownership and management in OPCs, as the sole member can also be the director. This can potentially lead to ethical concerns or conflicts of interest.

items.description: The Memorandum of Association outlines the objectives and scope of the company.

items.description: The Articles of Association define the internal rules and regulations of the company.

content.heading: Registration of One Person Company (OPC) in India
content.overview: In India, OPC company registration is facilitated through the SPICe+ (Simplified Proforma for Incorporating Company Electronically Plus) form, which simplifies the incorporation process. The process is divided into two parts: Part A for name approval and DIN/PAN application, and Part B for incorporation details. Below are the detailed steps for OPC registration online.

steps.title: Step 1: Obtain a Digital Signature Certificate (DSC)
steps.description: Secure a Digital Signature Certificate (DSC) for the intended director of the OPC. The DSC is utilized for electronically signing crucial documents.

steps.title: Step 2: Obtain Director Identification Number (DIN)
steps.description: Acquire a Director Identification Number (DIN) for the proposed director from the Ministry of Corporate Affairs (MCA).

steps.title: Step 3: Name Reservation
steps.description: Apply for name reservation through the MCA portal using Form SPICe+ (Part A). Ensure that the chosen name for your company is distinct and does not resemble any existing company or trademark.

steps.title: Step 4: Prepare MOA and AOA
steps.description: Draft the Memorandum of Association (MOA) and Articles of Association (AOA) for your company. These documents define the company's objectives and internal rules.

steps.title: Step 5: File the Forms
steps.description: File the necessary forms with the MCA to register One Person Company. Attach the relevant documents to the SPICe+ form, including MOA, AOA, declarations, proof of the registered office, nominee appointment, and other documents as required by the MCA.

steps.title: Step 6: Certificate of Incorporation
steps.description: Upon approval by the Registrar of Companies (ROC) and verification of compliance requirements, the ROC will issue a Certificate of Incorporation. The PAN (Permanent Account Number) and TAN (Tax Deduction and Collection Account Number) are generated automatically during this process.

content.heading: What is a Private Limited Company?
description: In India, a private limited company is a privately held entity with limited liability, and it ranks among the nation's most favored business structures. This popularity is primarily attributed to its numerous advantages, including limited liability protection, ease of formation and maintenance, and its status as a distinct legal entity. A private limited company enjoys legal separation from its owners and necessitates a minimum of two members and two directors for its operation.

keyCharacteristics.title: Limited Liability Protection
keyCharacteristics.description: Shareholders are liable only to the extent of their shareholding, and their personal assets remain safeguarded, even if the company faces financial setbacks.

keyCharacteristics.title: Separate Legal Entity
keyCharacteristics.description: The company has its own distinct legal identity. It can own property, engage in contracts, and initiate or defend legal actions under its name.

keyCharacteristics.title: Minimum Number of Shareholders
keyCharacteristics.description: A private company must have at least two shareholders but cannot exceed 200 shareholders.

keyCharacteristics.title: Minimum Number of Directors
keyCharacteristics.description: A private limited company requires a minimum of two directors, with at least one director being a citizen of India.

keyCharacteristics.title: Minimum Share Capital
keyCharacteristics.description: The company must have a minimum paid-up capital of Rs. 1 lakh or a higher amount as specified.

keyCharacteristics.title: Name of the Firm
keyCharacteristics.description: The company’s name must end with the words 'Private Limited.'

keyCharacteristics.title: Restrictions on Share Transfer
keyCharacteristics.description: Shares can only be transferred with the approval of the Board of Directors or following the company's Articles of Association.

keyCharacteristics.title: Prohibition on Public Invitation
keyCharacteristics.description: Private limited companies cannot invite the public to subscribe to their shares or debentures.

keyCharacteristics.title: Compliance Requirements
keyCharacteristics.description: Private limited companies must comply with various legal obligations, including maintaining proper financial records, conducting annual general meetings, and filing annual returns with the Registrar of Companies (ROC).

content.heading: Types of Private Limited Companies

items.title: Company Limited by Guarantee
items.description: Member liability is limited to the amount of guarantee specified in the Memorandum of Association. This guarantee is invoked only during winding up.

items.title: Unlimited Companies
items.description: Members of unlimited companies have unlimited personal liability for the company's debts and liabilities. However, they are still considered a separate legal entity, and individual members cannot be sued.

content.heading: Advantages of a Private Limited Company

items.title: Limited Liability
items.description: Shareholders' responsibility is restricted to the extent of their capital contribution, safeguarding personal assets from the company's financial obligations and liabilities.

items.title: Distinct Legal Identity
items.description: A Private Limited Company possesses an independent legal identity distinct from its proprietors. It has the capacity to own assets, engage in contractual agreements, and initiate or defend legal actions under its own name.

items.title: Continuous Existence

items.title: Ease of Funding

items.title: Tax Benefits

items.title: Credibility and Trust

items.title: Share Limits

items.title: Public Disclosure

items.title: Exit Complexity
items.description: Selling or leaving is more complicated than with other structures.

items.title: Slower Decisions

items.title: Company Name

items.title: Registered Office Address

content.heading: Company Registration Process in India
content.overview: To register a company in India involves a straightforward four-step company registration process:

steps.title: Step 1: Acquire a Digital Signature Certificate (DSC)

This involves providing essential details such as passport-sized photos, PAN, Aadhaar Card, phone number, and email address. steps.title: Step 5: Preparation and Submission of Incorporation Forms (SPICe+ MOA and AOA)

Obtain digital signatures from subscribers and professionals before submitting these documents to the MCA for approval. Additionally, file the AGILE-PRO-S form to register for GST, EPFO, ESIC, a bank account, and a shop and establishment license (which may be state-dependent).

content.heading: Trust & Trust Registration - An Overview
description: Individuals establish trusts to allocate a portion of their assets or property for the benefit of another person. A trust is a fiduciary relationship involving the trustor, trustee, and beneficiary. The involved parties are outlined in the trust deed when applying for registration for trust creation.

A trust is established when the trustor transfers a specific asset or property to the trustee for the ultimate benefit of the beneficiary. The beneficiary, who is typically a third party, may have a connection to both the trustor and the trustee.

Therefore, the relationship between the parties involved is essential in defining trust. According to the Indian Trusts Act of 1882, a trust is defined as a 'Relationship between the trustor and trustee to hold specific benefits for the beneficiary.'

content.heading: Parties involved in the Trust Registration Process

parties.description: The trustor is the person who establishes the trust. They are typically the owner of the assets or property being placed in the trust. The trustor transfers assets or property to the trustee, defining the terms and purpose of the trust.

The trustee is an individual or entity entrusted with the responsibility of managing and overseeing the trust. They hold and administer the trust property on behalf of the trustor and for the benefit of the beneficiary. The trustee is legally responsible for managing the trust in accordance with its terms.

The beneficiary is the person or entity for whom the trust is created. They are the intended recipient of the benefits, assets, or property held within the trust. The beneficiary may be a third party and is entitled to receive benefits according to the terms and conditions outlined in the trust agreement.

content.heading: Types of Trusts

items.title: Private Limited Trusts
items.description: Private Limited Trusts are established to carry out activities for specific individuals, families, or close associates. These trusts can have beneficiaries closely related to the trust'strust's founders. Private limited trusts are governed by The Trusts Act of 1882.

items.title: Public Limited Trusts
items.description: Public limited trusts are typically created to benefit the general public. They are often established for charitable, educational, and religious purposes and are governed by specific statutes such as the Religious Endowments Act of 1863, the Charitable and Religious Trust Act of 1920, or the Bombay Public Trust Act of 1950. Charitable and religious trusts are the most common types of public trusts in India.

items.title: Public Cum-Private Trust
items.description: This type of trust serves both public and private purposes. It can utilize its income for the benefit of the public and specific individuals or families. The beneficiaries of a public cum-private trust can be a combination of public and private individuals.

content.heading: Regulatory Authority and Laws for Trust Registration

Their role involves maintaining a comprehensive database of all registered trusts in the country. The registration process for private trusts is governed by the Trusts Act of 1882.
In the case of public trusts, no singular governing act applies uniformly. Public trusts in India must be registered with the relevant state authority as required by the applicable state act.

content.heading: Public Limited Company - An Overview
description: A Public Limited Company is a corporate entity that allows the general public to hold ownership through publicly traded shares. These shares can be bought and sold on established stock markets, enabling a wide range of investors, brokers, and traders to participate in the company's equity ownership.

Public Limited Companies are governed by stricter regulatory and reporting standards compared to private companies. In India, the Companies Act of 2013 outlines the rules governing these entities. A minimum of 7 members is required to start a Public Limited Company, and there is no upper limit on the number of shareholders.

The daily operations of a Public Limited Company are managed by an executive team, while ownership lies with shareholders who invest in the company's stock. These shareholders typically have voting rights, including the ability to elect the board of directors, which is responsible for appointing the executive team to oversee business operations.

content.heading: Key Characteristics of a Public Limited Company

features.title: Board of Directors
features.description: A public limited company must appoint at least three directors as per the Companies Act, with no upper limit on the number. The board of directors governs the company's management and strategic decision-making.

features.title: Company Name
features.description: It is legally required for public limited companies to include the word 'Limited' in their name. This indicates the company's status as a public entity, open to public investment and capable of trading shares on the stock market.

features.title: The Company's Prospectus
features.description: Public limited companies must prepare and issue a prospectus, providing detailed information about their operations and financial health. This document helps potential investors make informed decisions.

features.title: Paid-Up Capital
features.description: The Companies Act does not mandate a minimum initial share capital for public limited company registration. This offers flexibility for companies to structure their capital as per their needs and strategic goals.

content.heading: Types of Public Limited Companies
content.overview: Public limited companies can be categorized into two distinct types based on their stock trading and regulatory requirements. Here are the types:

items.title: Listed Company
items.description: This type of public limited company has its shares actively listed and available for trading on one or more stock exchanges. This allows for greater liquidity and exposure to a diverse pool of investors.

items.title: Unlisted Company
items.description: Unlike listed companies, unlisted public limited companies do not have their shares traded on any stock exchange. This results in less liquidity, lower public scrutiny, and fewer regulatory requirements, appealing to businesses seeking a broader shareholder base without full public trading complexities.

content.heading: Requirements for Registration of a Public Limited Company
content.overview: When registering a public limited company in India, it is essential to meet specific legal and financial requirements outlined under the Companies Act. Below are the key requirements for registration:

criteria.title: Board of Directors
criteria.description: A minimum of three directors is needed to establish a public limited company. Each director must have a valid Director Identification Number (DIN).

criteria.title: Authorised Share Capital
criteria.description: The company must have a minimum authorised share capital of Rs. 1 lakh to meet the financial requirements for registration.

criteria.title: Digital Signature Certificate (DSC)

criteria.title: Company Name

criteria.title: Foundational Documents

items.description: Documents proving residence are required for all members involved.

items.title: Digital Signature Certificates (DSC)

content.heading: Public Limited Company Registration Procedure
content.overview: Public limited company registration involves several structured steps that adhere to regulatory requirements. Here is a detailed guide to the procedure:

steps.title: Step 1: Obtain Digital Signature Certificates (DSC)
steps.description: Before starting the registration process, obtain Digital Signature Certificates (DSC) for all proposed directors and subscribers to the memorandum and articles of association. DSC is essential for filing the forms online on the Ministry of Corporate Affairs (MCA) portal.

steps.title: Step 2: Apply for Director Identification Number (DIN)
steps.description: Each proposed director must have a Director Identification Number (DIN). This can be applied for using the SPICe form, which also simplifies the application process. You need to provide proof of identity and address as part of the DIN application.

steps.title: Step 3: Check Company Name Availability
steps.description: Use the MCA online portal to check if your desired company name is available. It is important to ensure that the name does not infringe upon any existing trademarks or is not already in use. This step is crucial as it establishes the unique identity of your company.

steps.title: Step 4: File SPICe+ Form
steps.description: Once the name is approved, proceed to file the SPICe+ form. This comprehensive form is designed to cover all legalities for the incorporation of a company. Along with this form, you will need to submit the Memorandum of Association (MOA) and Articles of Association (AOA), which detail the constitution and rules governing the management of the company.

steps.title: Step 5: Certificate of Incorporation
steps.description: After the submission of the SPICe+ form and necessary documents, the Registrar of Companies (ROC) will review the application. Upon successful verification, the ROC issues a Certificate of Incorporation. This certificate is a legal document that marks the birth of the company and includes the company's Corporate Identification Number (CIN) and the date of incorporation.

steps.title: Step 6: Apply for PAN and TAN
steps.description: With the incorporation certificate in hand, the next step is to apply for the company's Permanent Account Number (PAN) and Tax Deduction and Collection Account Number (TAN). These are essential for all tax-related transactions and compliances.

steps.title: Step 7: Open a Company Bank Account
steps.description: Finally, open a bank account in the name of the company. You will need the Certificate of Incorporation, MOA, AOA, PAN, and other relevant documents to set up the bank account. This account will handle all monetary transactions of the company.

steps.title: Additional Steps
steps.description: Depending on the nature of the business and the specific sector it operates in, you may need additional approvals or registrations, such as GST registration, import/export code, or industry-specific licenses.

content.heading: Producer Company - An Overview
description: A Producer Company, also known as a Farmer Producer Company, is an officially recognized organization composed of farmers or agriculturists. Its main objective is to improve the livelihoods of its members, enhancing their resources, incomes, and profitability.

It operates as a hybrid between private limited companies and cooperative societies, combining the benefits of both. A Producer Company is registered under the Companies Act 2013 and adheres to democratic governance principles, ensuring each member has an equal say in decision-making, regardless of the number of shares they hold.
The structure of a Producer Company fosters long-term sustainability by focusing on the welfare of its members while ensuring effective management and resource utilization.

content.heading: Legal Framework for Producer Company Registration
description: A Producer Company is a legal entity established under the Companies Act, 1956, and it is governed by the provisions outlined in Section 465 of the Companies Act, 2013. This entity operates under the regulations specified in Part IX A of the Companies Act, 1956, with necessary modifications.

The objectives of a Producer Company incorporation must align with the activities outlined in Section 581B of the Companies Act, 1956. These regulations ensure the proper formation and governance of Producer Companies, enabling them to function effectively within the legal framework.

content.heading: Advantages of a Producer Company

The DSC is an electronic signature used to submit e-forms online securely. The documents required for obtaining a DSC include PAN Card of the Director, Aadhaar Card of the Director, Recent Photograph, Email ID, and Contact Number.

steps.title: Step 2: Obtain Director Identification Number (DIN)
steps.description: Subsequent to the acquisition of DSC, the next step involves obtaining the Director Identification Number (DIN) for each director. The DIN is a unique identifier for a director and is required for a director to be appointed in any company. This can be obtained by filing the DIR-3 form or through the SPICe+ form, accompanied by Self-attested identity proof (like PAN card), Address proof, and Recent photograph.

steps.title: Step 3: Name Reservation
steps.description: The name of the Producer Company must be unique and end with the words 'Producer Company.' For name reservation, Form SPICe+ is filed with the Registrar of Companies (ROC), proposing two names in order of preference and the significance behind those names. The ROC will then approve one of the proposed names based on availability and compliance with naming standards.

steps.title: Step 4: Preparation of Essential Documents
steps.description: Once the name is approved, the following vital documents need to be prepared for incorporation: Memorandum of Association (MoA), Articles of Association (AoA), Form INC-22 for the Registered Office, Form DIR-12 for Directors Appointment, Affidavit (if necessary), and Registered Office Proof.

steps.title: Step 5: Filing of Incorporation Application
steps.description: All the prepared documents and the application for incorporation are to be filed in Form SPICe+ with the ROC. The application must meticulously detail the company’s proposed structure, directors, and registered office.

steps.title: Step 6: ROC Verification and Certificate of Incorporation
steps.description: The ROC will scrutinise the application and the attached documents for compliance with legal requirements. Upon satisfaction, the ROC will issue the Certificate of Incorporation, proving that the company has been legally constituted. The company can then commence its business operations.

content.introduction: Setting up a subsidiary in India can be a transformative step for expanding your business operations and accessing one of the world's largest and most dynamic markets.
details: At Nandaguri Verifocus Legal LLP, we specialise in providing comprehensive and tailored services for the incorporation of a foreign subsidiary in India. content.heading: Subsidiary Company - An Overview
description: A subsidiary company is often referred to as a sister company, while the company that exercises control over it is known as the parent company or holding company. The parent company holds the authority to control the subsidiary company, either in part or entirely.

The registration process for a foreign subsidiary company in India is governed by the Companies Act of 2013. According to the Companies Act of 2013, a subsidiary company can be defined as a company in which a foreign corporate body or parent entity holds a minimum of 50% of the total share capital. In essence, the parent company exerts a significant influence and control over the subsidiary company.

content.heading: Types of Subsidiaries in India
content.overview: In India, subsidiaries are categorized based on the level of ownership and control exercised by the parent company. Below are the two primary types:

items.title: Wholly-Owned Subsidiary
items.description: In a wholly-owned subsidiary, the parent company possesses 100% ownership of the subsidiary's shares. However, wholly-owned subsidiaries can only be established in sectors that permit 100% Foreign Direct Investment (FDI).

items.title: Subsidiary Company
items.description: In this category of subsidiary, the parent company owns 50% of the subsidiary's shares. Before proceeding with establishing a foreign subsidiary company in India, obtaining approval from the Reserve Bank of India is a crucial prerequisite to ensure compliance with foreign investment regulations.

content.heading: Advantages of Indian Subsidiary Company Registration
overview: The incorporation of a foreign subsidiary in India offers numerous benefits, making it an attractive option for businesses looking to expand their operations. Below are the key advantages:

items.title: Entry into the Indian Market
items.description: India's competitive environment offers numerous investment opportunities, attracting foreign entrepreneurs to establish their subsidiary companies in the country.

items.title: Foreign Direct Investment (FDI) in India
items.description: FDI allows foreign companies to invest in Indian private companies through share subscriptions or acquisitions. The 2020 provision requiring prior approval for investments from bordering countries further emphasizes Indian subsidiary registration as a strategic choice.

items.title: Perpetual Succession
items.description: This ensures a company's existence remains intact despite changes in management, transfers of membership, or insolvency, providing stability and continuity.

items.title: Limited Liability
items.description: Shareholders and directors benefit from limited liability, protecting their personal assets. The company itself bears responsibility for its debts, shielding its stakeholders' personal wealth.

items.title: Scope of Diversification
items.description: Establishing an Indian subsidiary enables foreign businesses to expand operations, contributing to the growth of the Indian economy and introducing diverse goods and services.

items.title: Separate Legal Identity
items.description: Under the Companies Act, a company is a distinct legal entity, enabling it to engage in contracts, initiate legal actions, and operate independently of its shareholders and directors.

items.title: Property Ownership and Rental
items.description: As a legal entity, a subsidiary company can purchase or rent properties in India for business activities, ensuring seamless operations and aligning with perpetual succession principles.

content.heading: Regulatory Authorities for Indian Subsidiary Company Registration
description: The process of registering a subsidiary company in India is governed by several regulatory authorities to ensure legal compliance and proper oversight. Key authorities such as the Ministry of Corporate Affairs (MCA), Registrar of Companies (RoC), and Reserve Bank of India (RBI) play pivotal roles in overseeing the incorporation and operational compliance of foreign subsidiaries in India.

content.heading: Requirements and Key Facts about Company Registration in India
description: Registering a foreign subsidiary in India involves meeting specific legal, operational, and compliance requirements. Here are the essential elements to consider:

items.title: Company Name
items.description: Your new business requires a unique name that is distinct from existing businesses' names or trademarks.

items.title: Shareholders
items.description: The parent company can hold 100% of the shares, or any combination of two foreign nationals can be shareholders. It is not mandatory to have an Indian resident as a shareholder.

items.title: Share Capital
items.description: India does not impose a minimum capital requirement for company registration.

items.title: Directors
items.description: A minimum of two directors is mandatory, with at least one director being an Indian resident. Nominee directorship services can be provided if required.

items.title: Registered Address
items.description: Every company in India must have a registered address that is officially recorded in government records. Virtual office address services are available to meet this requirement.

items.title: Annual General Meeting (AGM)
items.description: According to the Companies Act, every Indian company must conduct at least one general meeting annually, in addition to two board meetings.

items.title: Company Secretary
items.description: It is mandatory to file three secretarial returns each year, which are handled by a company secretary. A statutory auditor must also be appointed.

items.title: Taxation
description: Professional fees, including government fees, are applicable for company registration.
Following incorporation, companies are subject to a profit tax rate of approximately 25.36%.
GST (Goods and Services Tax) is applicable to domestic sales, with monthly GST returns and one annual tax return required.

items.title: Annual Compliance
description: India has unique compliance requirements, including mandatory statutory audits even for smaller companies.
Foreign subsidiary companies in India must appoint a statutory auditor and submit annual filings.

steps.title: Determine the Type of Company
steps.description: Decide on the type of company you want to establish for incorporation of a foreign subsidiary in India.

steps.title: Obtain Digital Signature Certificate (DSC)
steps.description: Since the registration process is conducted online, obtain a Digital Signature Certificate (DSC) for the proposed directors of the company. The DSC is used for electronically signing the necessary documents during the registration process.

steps.title: Apply for a Director Identification Number (DIN)
steps.description: Directors must obtain a Director Identification Number (DIN) from the Ministry of Corporate Affairs (MCA) by submitting the DIN application online.

steps.title: Name Approval
steps.description: Choose a unique name for your subsidiary company and apply for its approval through the MCA's online portal, adhering to the naming guidelines provided by the MCA.

steps.title: Draft Memorandum of Association (MoA) and Articles of Association (AoA)
steps.description: Prepare these legal documents to outline the company’s objectives, rules, and regulations, following the Companies Act 2013.

steps.title: File Incorporation Documents
steps.description: After name approval, file incorporation documents, including the MoA, AoA, and other forms, with the Registrar of Companies (ROC) through the MCA’s online portal using the SPICe+ form.

steps.title: Payment of Registration Fees
steps.description: Pay the required registration fees to the ROC based on the authorized capital of the subsidiary company.

steps.title: Obtain a Certificate of Incorporation (COI)
steps.description: If all submitted documents and information are in order, the ROC issues a Certificate of Incorporation, officially confirming the Indian subsidiary registration.

steps.title: Apply for Permanent Account Number (PAN) and Tax Registration
steps.description: After receiving the CoI, apply for a PAN and Tax Deduction and Collection Account Number (TAN) from the Income Tax Department.

steps.title: Open Bank Account
steps.description: Open a bank account in the name of the foreign subsidiary company in India.

steps.title: Obtain a GST Number
steps.description: Register for GST to comply with taxation requirements if the company is engaging in business activities.

steps.title: Initiate Business Operations
steps.description: Once the incorporation process is complete, the subsidiary company can commence its business operations.

content.heading: Compliance Requirements for Indian Subsidiary Registration
description: To establish a legal and valid Indian subsidiary company registration, adherence to specific regulations is mandatory. These regulations ensure legal compliance, transparency, and alignment with Indian corporate governance standards.

items.title: Foreign Exchange Management Act (FEMA)
items.description: Foreign companies operating in India must adhere to the foreign exchange laws and regulations outlined in the Foreign Exchange Management Act, 1999, ensuring proper management of foreign currency transactions.

items.title: Companies Act, 2013
items.description: Indian subsidiary companies are required to comply with the provisions of the Companies Act, 2013, which governs the incorporation, operation, and dissolution of companies in India.

items.title: Reserve Bank of India (RBI) Compliances
items.description: The Reserve Bank of India enforces several foreign exchange management compliances to regulate financial transactions involving foreign subsidiaries.

items.title: Income Tax Act, 1961
items.description: Subsidiary companies must file annual income tax returns under the Income Tax Act, 1961. The current corporate tax rate in India is approximately 25%.

items.title: Annual Returns
items.description: Companies are required to file annual returns with the Ministry of Corporate Affairs (MCA) and the Registrar of Companies, ensuring compliance with statutory reporting obligations.

items.title: SEBI (Listing Obligations and Disclosure Regulations)
items.description: If the subsidiary lists its securities on a stock exchange, it must adhere to the Securities and Exchange Board of India (SEBI) regulations, ensuring transparency and investor protection.

content.heading: Taxation of Indian Subsidiary Companies
paragraphs: Indian subsidiary companies are subject to specific taxation policies, which apply to income earned both within and outside India.
description: Taxes are levied on all income earned within or outside India, including dividends from foreign subsidiaries.
Tax rates for foreign subsidiaries in India include a 50% tax rate for royalty received for technical services from the government or any Indian entity, and a 40% tax rate for other income.
A surcharge of 2% is applied to income between Rs. 1 Crore and Rs. 10 Crores, and a 5% surcharge is levied on payments above Rs. 10 Crores.
In addition, a 4% health and education cess is added to the total tax amount, further impacting the overall tax burden for Indian subsidiaries.

content.heading: FDI in Private Limited Company
paragraphs: 100% Foreign Direct Investment is allowed in most sectors. A few sectors, however, require prior approval from the Central Government for foreign investments. These sectors include private security agencies, civil aviation, mining, print media and broadcasting, satellite establishment and operation, pharmaceuticals, and trading of food products.
Foreign entities can establish wholly-owned Indian subsidiaries with 100% ownership, subject to specific qualifications.

points.title: For a Private Limited Company
description: No minimum capital requirement
Minimum of 2 directors (at least one must be a resident of India)
Minimum of 2 shareholders

points.title: For a Public Company

At least seven shareholders

content.heading: Trade License
description: A Trade License is an essential document required for the legal operation of businesses in India. It ensures the business complies with various local regulations related to health, safety, and sanitation.

Obtaining a Trade License is mandatory for most businesses across various industries. Whether it's a small shop, restaurant, or a manufacturing unit, a Trade License ensures that your business meets the regulatory requirements imposed by local authorities.

A trade license is an official document or certificate issued by the Municipal Corporation of a state granting permission to the applicant (individual seeking to establish a business) to engage in a specific trade or business activity within a designated area or location. This license ensures that the business complies with all safety standards mandated by the State Municipal Corporation, safeguarding residents from potential health hazards.

It’s important to note that a trade license restricts the holder from engaging in any trade or business activity other than the one for which it was issued. Additionally, the license does not confer any property ownership to the holder.

criteria.description: The business must fall under a category that requires a Trade License, such as manufacturing, trading, or providing services.

criteria.title: Location
criteria.description: The business must be based in an area where the local municipality or city corporation issues Trade Licenses.

criteria.title: Legal Entity

content.introduction: If your business sells food or edible items, adhering to the FSSAI (Food Safety and Standards Authority of India) Act regulations is crucial. This legal framework requires your business to be officially registered with the government and obtain a license from the Food Safety Department.
details: Whether you are a small-scale or large-scale food business engaged in manufacturing, storing, transporting, or distributing food, obtaining FSSAI registration or a license, depending on your business's size and nature, is essential.
Complying with these regulations ensures the country's food products' safety and quality.
At Solocorp, we understand the significance of obtaining an FSSAI license registration for your business. We're committed to making the FSSAI License online process seamless and hassle-free.

content.heading: Who Requires an FSSAI License?
description: In India, any business engaged in activities such as making, storing, distributing, selling, or importing food products is obligated to secure an FSSAI (Food Safety and Standards Authority of India) license.
This encompasses restaurants, catering services, food processing factories, food delivery ventures, and online food sellers requiring FSSAI license apply online.
Both individuals and companies participating in these operations must obtain an FSSAI license online to operate lawfully within India.

content.heading: FSSAI Registration
description: FSSAI Registration is mandatory for small-scale food manufacturers or Food Business Operators (FBOs) whose turnover is below Rs. 12 Lakhs unless the FBO falls under the category of compulsory licensing.

Petty FBOs involved in producing or selling food items, such as hawkers, petty retailers, itinerant vendors, temporary stall-holders, or small-scale food industry enterprises, need to obtain an FSSAI registration certificate if they meet the following conditions:
1. **Annual Turnover**: The turnover should be less than Rs. 12 Lakhs.
2. **Production Capacity**: Food products (excluding milk, meat, and fish) should not exceed 100 liters or kg daily.
3. **Milk Procurement**: The milk procurement, handling, and collection should be limited to 500 liters daily.
4. **Slaughtering Capacity**: Slaughtering capacity should be up to ten small animals, two large animals, or 50 poultry birds per day or less.
5. **Food Distribution**: Engaging in food distribution at religious or social gatherings, except as a caterer.
The FSSAI registration number, consisting of 14 digits, is issued by the State Licensing Authority. Notably, the first digit of the registration number begins with the digit 2.

content.heading: FSSAI License for Food Businesses
description: An FSSAI License is a crucial requirement for enterprises with a turnover exceeding Rs. 12 lakhs and for Food Business Operators (FBOs) engaged in food processing and manufacturing.
This license is divided into two primary types: Central FSSAI License and State FSSAI License.
The FSSAI license is identified by a 14-digit code with the initial digit 1. The choice between a State or Central license depends on the scale of the business.
The validity of the license must be maintained through FSSAI License Renewal. With the FSSAI license online check, you can check the authenticity and validity of your license.

content.heading: State License
description: FBOs such as medium-scale processors, manufacturers, traders, marketers, or transporters fall within the jurisdiction of the FSSAI state license, which the respective state government grants.
Medium-sized FBOs with an annual turnover surpassing Rs. 12 lakhs but not exceeding Rs. 20 Crores are required to obtain a state license.
A central license becomes mandatory if an FBO's annual turnover exceeds Rs. 20 Crores.

content.heading: Central License
description: Large-scale enterprises involved in food processing, transportation, manufacturing, and international trade of food products are obligated to obtain the FSSAI central license.
An FBO is classified as a large business if its annual turnover exceeds Rs. 20 Crores, necessitating acquiring the FSSAI central license from the Central Government.

content.heading: Halal Certification
description: Halal Certification is predominantly obtained for food and food-related products, and it is essential in Islamic countries.

The term 'Halal' is derived from the Quran, which means 'permitted' or 'lawful.' According to Islamic law, the Shariah, the Certification is used for Food and other consumables permissible for consumption.

Halal Certification emphasizes cleanliness in all aspects of a person's life, and Halal foods ensure that the food consumed by individuals is clean, hygienic, and does not harm their health or well-being.

The Certification guarantees that the food product is safe for consumption. With the increasing awareness of Halal foods, more businesses are seeking Halal Certification for their products, restaurants, premises, etc.

content.heading: Halal Certification in India
description: In India, a Halal Certificate is a document issued by a Halal certification body or authority confirming that a product or service complies with Islamic dietary laws and guidelines and is permissible or 'Halal' for consumption by Muslims.
Halal Certification in India is significant for food and beverage products, pharmaceuticals, and personal care products. It can also apply to other non-food products or services.

Businesses seeking Halal Certification in India must comply with the relevant standards and guidelines set forth by the certification body or authority and undergo a rigorous inspection and audit process to ensure compliance.

content.heading: Types of Halal Certification
description: The type of Halal Certification varies depending on the nature of the business.
Typically, restaurants, hotels, slaughterhouses, and packaging and labeling materials seek Halal Certification to ensure they meet the requirements of Muslim consumers.

Halal Certification is not limited to food production alone. Other products, such as non-alcoholic beverages, raw materials for food processing, pharmaceutical and healthcare products, traditional herbal products, cosmetics, personal care products, cleaning products, and everyday consumer goods, can also obtain Halal Certification.

Halal Certification Bodies offer Certification under various schemes, including the Food and Catering Scheme, Restaurant Scheme, Industrial Scheme, Abattoir Scheme, Warehouse or Storage Scheme, and Product Endorsement Scheme.

content.heading: Validity of Halal Certificate
content.description: The validity of a Halal Certificate typically lasts for one year. However, it is subject to certain conditions and may be revoked if the product or process no longer meets the Halal Certification requirements.

items.title: Ingredients
items.description: All ingredients used in the product must be Halal. This means that the ingredients must not come from non-Halal animals or contain any non-Halal additives or preservatives.

items.title: Manufacturing Process
items.description: The manufacturing process used to produce the product must also be Halal. This includes the use of equipment and utensils that are free from non-Halal substances and the use of Halal-certified cleaning products.

items.title: Packaging
items.description: The packaging material used for the product must also be Halal. This means it must not contain any non-Halal substances or come into contact with non-Halal substances during manufacturing.

items.title: Storage and Transportation
items.description: The product must be stored and transported to ensure it remains Halal. This includes using dedicated storage areas and vehicles free from non-Halal substances.

items.title: Certification
items.description: The business must obtain a Halal Certificate from a recognized Halal Certification Body that verifies that the product and manufacturing process meet Halal standards. In India, Halal certification bodies must be registered with the Halal Board of India.

items.title: Compliance
items.description: The business must comply with all relevant laws and regulations related to Halal Certification in India, such as the Halal Certification Regulations of India.

content.heading: Halal Certification Procedure
content.overview: This step-by-step guide explains the procedure for obtaining Halal Certification in India, from application to final certification.

steps.title: Step 1: Application
steps.description: The business wishing to obtain Halal Certification must apply to one of the Certification Bodies. At Solocorp, we help businesses understand the requirements for obtaining Halal Certification and provide guidance on the application process.

steps.title: Step 2: Conducting the Audit
steps.description: After the business has submitted its application, a team of auditors (typically one Shariah Auditor and one Technical Auditor) will conduct an on-site inspection. The auditors will review documentation, processing, handling, storage, display, cleanliness, tools, and packaging to ensure compliance. The business may need to provide a certificate of analysis and Halal certificates for individual components. Once the audit is completed, the audit report is signed.

steps.title: Step 3: Certification
steps.description: The Halal Certification Body's Technical Committee reviews the audit report and relevant documents. If the auditors' report is satisfactory and the business meets the criteria, the Halal Certification Body will issue the Halal Certificate. The certificate includes the name and address of the business, the scope of Certification, and the validity period.

ICEGATE facilitates the electronic filing of customs documents such as Shipping Bills for exports and Bills of Entry for imports.

items.description: IEC holders planning to file documents on ICEGATE are urged to register promptly through the new Registration Module to facilitate their document filing processes.

items.title: Digital Signature Certificate (DSC) Requirement
items.description: Users are advised to have their Class III Individual Type DSC tokens ready and plugged into their systems before starting the registration process. DSCs must be uploaded during registration to authenticate the user's identity and ensure secure transactions.

items.title: CHA Employee Registration
items.description: Only G-Card holders can register as Custom House Agent (CHA) employees. This is because G-Card holders are authorized to digitally sign documents using DSC, a capability not extended to H-Card holders.

items.title: Parent and Child User Registration
items.description: An entity can register one parent user on ICEGATE, with subsequent users registered as child users under the primary account, facilitating structured access and management.

items.title: ICES Registration Number Utilization
items.description: The ICES (Indian Customs EDI System) registration number provided during the registration process is used to access information from ICES directories and is displayed for verification purposes.

items.title: Data Collection and Verification

It helps improve transparency and reduces the risk of financial fraud by ensuring that each entity's details are easily accessible and consistently recorded in financial markets worldwide. Each LEI Code provides key reference information that enables clear and unique identification of legal entities participating in financial transactions, such as their name, location, and information concerning the company structure.

content.heading: What is LEI Code?
description: A Legal Entity Identifier (LEI) is a distinct 20-digit alphanumeric code assigned to registered legal entities globally. This code enhances market transparency by facilitating the straightforward identification of entities involved in financial transactions. It is important to note that the LEI differs from local registration numbers or CINs provided by regional regulatory bodies.
LEI adheres to a standardised universal format recognised worldwide. This code adheres to the ISO 17442 standard developed by the International Organization for Standardization (ISO).

An LEI code can be obtained from any of the Local Operating Units (LOUs) accredited by the Global Legal Entity Identifier Foundation (GLEIF), which oversees the implementation and use of LEIs worldwide. In India, the Legal Entity Identifier India Ltd. (LEIL) serves as an official issuer recognised by the Reserve Bank of India (RBI).

content.heading: LEI Code Applicability
content.overview: Here's a breakdown of the entities required to have an LEI:

items.title: Financial Institutions
items.description: Banks, insurance companies, and non-banking financial companies must have an LEI to facilitate the monitoring and regulation of financial transactions.

items.title: Stock Market Participants
items.description: Entities listed on stock exchanges or those participating in the depository system need an LEI, as mandated by the Securities and Exchange Board of India (SEBI).

items.title: Derivatives and Forex Markets
items.description: Participants in over-the-counter derivatives and foreign exchange markets are required to possess an LEI to help track transactions and manage counterparty risk.

items.title: High-Value Transaction Entities
items.description: Any legal entity involved in transactions exceeding Rs.50 crore through systems like the Real Time Gross Settlement (RTGS) must have an LEI.

items.title: Large Borrowers
items.description: Entities with fund-based or non-fund-based exposures of Rs.5 crore or more, as well as corporations with financial exposures of Rs.50 crore or more sourced from banks, UCBs, NBFCs, and AIFIs, are required to obtain an LEI.

items.title: Public Securities Transactions
items.description: Issuers, guarantors, borrowers, or security providers dealing with securities issued to the public, listed on a stock exchange, or included in the depository system must secure an LEI.

content.heading: Importance of LEI Code
description: The importance of a Legal Entity Identifier (LEI) code lies in its ability to enhance transparency and security within the global financial system. Here are the key reasons why LEI codes are crucial:

items.title: Improved Transparency
items.description: LEIs clearly identify legal entities engaged in financial transactions worldwide, reducing the ambiguity that can arise from similar names or different business units within the same company.

items.title: Risk Management
items.description: By providing precise and accessible data about entities, LEIs help financial institutions and regulators manage counterparty and credit risks more effectively.

items.title: Regulatory Compliance
items.description: Many regulatory frameworks require LEIs for reporting and compliance purposes. Entities without an LEI may face restrictions or be unable to participate in certain financial transactions.

items.title: Operational Efficiency
items.description: LEIs simplify various operational processes by providing each entity with a standardised, universal identifier. This can streamline transactions, reporting, and record-keeping.

items.title: Fraud Prevention
items.description: With LEIs, the financial sector can more easily trace transactions back to the entities involved, helping to detect and prevent fraudulent activities.

items.title: Market Integrity
items.description: LEIs contribute to the integrity of financial markets by ensuring that all participants are clearly and consistently identified, making it easier to assess and control systemic risk.

content.heading: LEI Code Validity
description: LEI codes are valid for one year from the date of issuance and require annual renewal to ensure the information they contain remains current and accurate. For example, an LEI issued on February 1, 2023, must be renewed by February 1, 2024.

content.heading: Documents Required for LEI Code
content.overview: Here are the documents required for obtaining an LEI, as specified by LEIL:

items.title: Audited Financial Statements
items.description: These are mandatory and provide a detailed account of the financial health and transactions of the entity.

items.title: Letter of Authority

content.introduction: Professional tax is a direct tax levied on persons earning an income by either practicing a profession, employment, calling, or trade. Unlike income tax imposed by the Central Government, professional tax is levied by the government of a state or union territory in India. In the case of salaried and wage earners, the professional tax is liable to be deducted by the Employer from the salary/wages, and the same is to be deposited to the state government. In the case of other classes of individuals, this tax is liable to be paid by the employee himself. The tax calculation and amount collected may vary from one State to another, but it has a maximum limit of Rs. 2500/- per year.
details: Professional tax registration is mandatory for businesses or professionals operating in states or union territories that levy this tax.
For employers, professional tax must be deducted from employees' wages and paid to the respective state government, while individuals practicing a profession must pay the tax themselves.
The rate and method of professional tax collection vary from state to state, and businesses must comply with local regulations to avoid penalties.

content.heading: Professional Tax Applicability
description: Professional tax is applicable to a wide range of individuals and entities engaged in various professions, trades, and employment across India.
The following classes of persons are subject to professional tax:
- An Individual
- A Hindu Undivided Family (HUF)
- A Company/Firm/Co-operative Society/Association of persons or a body of individuals, whether incorporated or not
Professionals earning income from salary or practicing a profession, such as lawyers, teachers, doctors, chartered accountants, etc., are required to pay professional tax.

content.heading: Professional Tax Rate
description: The maximum amount payable per annum towards professional tax is INR 2,500.
Professional tax is calculated based on the gross income of the individual and is usually deducted monthly as a slab amount.
The Commercial Taxes Department of a state/union territory is responsible for collecting professional tax based on predetermined tax slabs, which vary from state to state and union territory.
The tax is calculated on the annual taxable income of the individual. It can be paid either annually or on a monthly basis.

content.heading: Who Pays Professional Tax?
description: For salaried and wage earners, the professional tax is liable to be deducted by the employer from the salary or wages, and the employer is responsible for depositing it with the state government.
Self-employed persons who practice a profession or carry out a trade on their own and fall under the ambit of professional tax are liable to pay the tax themselves directly to the state government.

content.heading: Employer’s Responsibility for Professional Tax
description: The owner of a business is responsible for deducting professional tax from the salaries of employees and paying the collected amount to the appropriate government department.
The employer must also furnish a return to the tax department in the prescribed form within the specified time, including proof of the tax payment.
Failure to include proof of payment in the return will result in the return being considered incomplete and invalid by the tax department.

content.heading: Exemptions for Payment of Professional Tax

items.title: Parents of children with permanent disability or mental disability
items.description: Parents of children who have permanent disability or mental disability are exempt from paying professional tax.

items.title: Members of the forces
items.description: Members of the forces as defined in the Army Act, 1950, the Air Force Act, 1950, and the Navy Act, 1957, including members of auxiliary forces or reservists, serving in the State, are exempt.

items.title: Badli workers in the textile industry
items.description: Badli workers in the textile industry are exempt from paying professional tax.

items.title: Individuals suffering from permanent physical disability
items.description: An individual suffering from a permanent physical disability, including blindness, is exempt from professional tax.

items.title: Women working under Mahila Pradhan Kshetriya Bachat Yojana

content.heading: FDI Filing with RBI
description: Foreign Direct Investment (FDI) filing refers to reporting the inflow of foreign investment in an Indian company to the Reserve Bank of India (RBI).
This reporting is mandatory for Indian companies that receive foreign investments in equity shares, compulsorily convertible preference shares or debentures, and warrants or partly-paid shares.

content.heading: Applicable Regulation on FDI Filing with RBI

content.heading: Conditions Required for Foreign Direct Investment (FDI)

details: FDI is permitted under two routes in various sectors:

content.heading: Penalty for Non-Filing of Form FCGPR with RBI
description: If a company fails to file the FCGPR form within the prescribed timeline, it will face penalties.
The penalty for delayed reporting is 1% of the total investment amount, with a minimum of INR 5,000 and a maximum of INR 5 lakhs per month or part thereof for the first six months of delay.
After six months, the penalty rate doubles to 2% per month until the non-compliance is rectified.
The penalty must be paid online into a designated account with the RBI.
Therefore, it is crucial for companies to file the FCGPR form within the stipulated time to avoid any penalties.

content.heading: Process for Filing FCGPR with RBI
content.overview: Filing Foreign Direct Investment (FDI) with the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) using Form FCGPR involves several steps to ensure compliance with the regulations.

steps.title: Step 1: Obtain Authorized Dealer (AD) Code
steps.description: The first step is to obtain an Authorized Dealer (AD) Code from a bank authorized by the RBI. The AD bank acts as an intermediary between the company and the RBI and verifies the information provided in the FCGPR form.

steps.title: Step 2: Registration of Entity User on Firms Portal
steps.description: The Indian company must register as an Entity User on the RBI's online reporting portal (Firms Portal). The company must provide its details and obtain a User ID and Password.

steps.title: Step 3: Creation of Entity Master
steps.description: Once registered on the Firms Portal, the company must create an Entity Master by providing details such as name, address, PAN, TAN, and other relevant information.

steps.title: Step 4: Registration for Business Users on Firms Portal
steps.description: After creating the Entity Master, the company must register the Business Users authorized to access the Firms Portal and submit the FCGPR form. The Business Users must provide their details and obtain a User ID and Password.

steps.title: Step 5: Preparation of Form FCGPR
steps.description: After obtaining the AD Code, the company must prepare the FCGPR form in the required format. The form can be accessed on the RBI's online reporting portal.

steps.title: Step 6: Provide Relevant Information
steps.description: The company must provide relevant information in the FCGPR form, including details of the foreign investor, the amount and type of investment, percentage of equity held, sector of investment, and other relevant details.

steps.title: Step 7: Signing and Certification
steps.description: The FCGPR form must be signed and certified by the company's authorized signatory and the AD bank's authorized signatory. The certification confirms the accuracy of the form's information.

steps.title: Step 8: Reporting of FDI Received
steps.description: The Indian company must report the receipt of FDI within 30 days of receipt using Form FCGPR on the Firms Portal, ensuring all required documents are uploaded.

steps.title: Step 9: Submission of Form
steps.description: Once the FCGPR form is duly completed and certified, it must be submitted to the AD bank electronically on the RBI's online reporting portal within 30 days of receiving the FDI.

steps.title: Step 10: Acknowledgement Receipt
steps.description: After submission of the FCGPR form, the Firms Portal generates an acknowledgment receipt. The company must download and save the acknowledgment receipt for future reference.

steps.title: Step 11: Follow-up
steps.description: The company must follow up with the AD bank to ensure that the RBI has accepted the FCGPR form and address any discrepancies if required.

content.heading: Introduction to FLA Return
description: The Foreign Liabilities and Asset (FLA) Return is a mandatory annual report for Indian organisations that have received foreign direct investment (FDI) or have invested in FDI overseas.
This report, submitted to the Reserve Bank of India (RBI), collects detailed information on the foreign liabilities and assets listed on these entities' balance sheets.
Governed by the Foreign Exchange Management Act, 1999 (FEMA), the FLA Return thoroughly regulates India's foreign exchange and international financial transactions.

content.heading: Applicability of FLA Return
description: The FLA Return must be filed by a range of entities, including:
Companies established under the Companies Act, 2013.
Limited Liability Partnerships (LLPs) formed under the Limited Liability Partnership Act 2008.

Various other organisations, such as SEBI-registered Alternative Investment Funds (AIFs), Partnership Firms, and Public-Private Partnerships (PPPs), engaged in foreign direct investment activities within India or abroad.

content.heading: Non-Applicability of FLA Return
description: The requirement to submit the FLA Return does not apply to entities in the following situations:
If the entity has neither received Foreign Direct Investment (FDI) nor made any overseas investments in the current or previous years.
If the entity’s foreign investment is limited to sharing application money without any outstanding FDI or overseas direct investment by the end of March of the reporting year.

If non-resident shareholders have sold their shares to residents within the reporting period, and the entity has only issued shares to non-residents, the invested capital cannot be converted back into foreign currency and taken out of the country.
